Stack<T>

A stack is an abstract data type that serves as a collection of elements, with two main principal operations:

  • Push, which adds an element to the collection, and
  • Pop, which removes the most recently added element that was not yet removed.

The order in which elements come off a stack gives rise to its alternative name, LIFO (last in, first out). Additionally, a peek operation may give access to the top without modifying the stack.

Usage

									
import { Stack } from '@samavati/tsds';

// instantiate new Stack
const stack = new Stack();

The stack supports iterator protocols allowing it to be used with the for...of

									
import { Stack } from '@samavati/tsds';

stack.push(1);
stack.push(2);
stack.push(3);

for (const item of stack) {
	console.log(item)
}

// 3
// 2
// 1

Properties

length

Definition

Gets the number of elements contained in the Stack.

Property Value

number

Example
									
const stack = new Stack<number>();

stack.push(1);
stack.push(2);
stack.push(3);

stack.length // => 3
Remarks

Retrieving the value of this property is an O(1) operation.

Methods

clear

Definition

Removes all objects from the Stack.

Example
									
const stack = new Stack<number>();

stack.push(1);
stack.push(2);
stack.push(3);

stack.length // => 3
stack.clear()
stack.length // => 0

includes

Definition

Determines whether an element is in the Stack.

Parameters
item T
The object to locate in the Stack.
Returns

boolean

true if item is found in the Stack; otherwise, false.

Example
									
const stack = new Stack<number>();

stack.push(1);
stack.push(2);
stack.push(3);

stack.includes(2) // => true
stack.includes(10) // => false
Remarks

This method is an O(n) operation.

peek

Definition

Returns the object at the top of the Stackwithout removing it.

Returns

T

The object at the top of the Stack.

Example
									
const stack = new Stack<number>();

stack.push(1);
stack.push(2);
stack.push(3);

stack.peek() // => 3
Remarks

This method is an O(1) operation.

pop

Definition

Removes and returns the object at the top of the Stack.

Returns

T

The object at the top of the Stack.

Example
									
const stack = new Stack<number>();

stack.push(1);
stack.push(2);
stack.push(3);

stack.pop() // => 3
stack.length // => 2
Remarks

This method is an O(1) operation.

push

Definition

Inserts an object at the top of the Stack.

Parameters
value T
The object to push onto the Stack.
Example
									
const stack = new Stack<number>();

stack.push(1);
stack.push(2);
stack.push(3);

stack.length // => 3
Remarks

This method is an O(1) operation.

toArray

Definition

Returns the entire Stack<T> to a compatible one-dimensional Array

Example
									
const stack = new Stack<number>();

stack.push(1);
stack.push(2);
stack.push(3);

stack.toArray() // => [3, 2, 1]
Remarks

This method is an O(n) operation.
